trial_identification.studytitle: Post Amputation Phantom Limb Pain Study
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Can Pregabalin prevent persistent post amputation pain?

conditions.healthcondition: Persistent phantom limb pain post amputation

interventions.interventions: One month course of oral pregabalin commencing with a single preoperative 150md dose of pregabalin, followed by 75mg oral pregabalin BD for 7 days after surgery, then increasing to 75-150mg bd for the following 21 days, a total of 28 days of pregabalin
interventions.comparator: Placebo- calcium carbonate packaged to appear identical to the pregabalin capsule

primaryOutcome.outcome: reduction of incidence of phantom pain in treatment group using chi square testing: significant pain versus no significant pain
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 1 week, one month and six months post amputation surgery

secondaryOutcome.outcome: improvement in acute postoperative pain which will be measured using the verbal response scale (VRS)
improvements in analgesic requirements after discharge from acute care hospital
improvement in psychological status after lower limb amputation
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: 24hrs, 48hrs, 1 week, 1 month and 6 months post surgery measured using the Hospital and anxiety scale (HADS)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Patient able to provide own informed consent. there is sufficient ime before proposed surgery to allow absorption of loading dose of pregabalin, minimum 2hrs Patient is suitable for standard general anaesthetic (GA) regimen and able to use patient controlled analgesia (PCA) for postop analgesia
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Current use of gabapentin Unable to give consent epilepsy pregnancy lactation significant renal impairment galactos metabolic disorders

trial_design.sequence: permutted blocks with stratified allocation by site
